text:
Whenever you win, people will immediately assume you took a shortcut. 

Because the idea that you ran the entire race and won before they even got off the couch hurts their own ego so much, you cheating is the only reality their ego can stomach.
You always looks like an overnight success because they just found out about you.

How to stay poor:

Assume that anyone who makes more money than you is unethical.

When everyone leaves a party just as you get there, then you realize it’s your house and you need to clean it all by morning because important people are coming by tomorrow.

It’s 10 people’s worth of work. 

But it’s too late to call anyone and it has to get done tonight.

And it’s just you.

You stay up all night cleaning the house on your own from a mess you didn’t make. 

Mop. Dishes. Trash. So much trash. Bottles. Empties. Spills. Reorganize…

…It’s dawn and the house is starting to look presentable.

Just as the important people are supposed to show up, you get a text: “sorry can’t make it. We’ll have to reschedule.”

And there you are, alone, after spending all night cleaning up a mess you didn’t make for people who ended up not showing up. 

And as much as you’d like to sulk, or be tired, you’ve got too much other stuff you have to do.

You’re two years in. It feels like there’s no end in sight and you’re not sure when it will get better. 

***
And rather than the social media glorification, that’s what entrepreneurship feels like 99% of the time.

A test of will, not intellect.

More people are terrified to lose what they have than to not achieve what they’re capable of.

When those fears flip, you become dangerous.
Entrepreneurship is a test of will, not intellect.

It’s rare that a definition stops me in my tracks…

This one by @DrKashey did. 

In response to someone who asked: 
“I’m trying to figure out who I really am…if I’m being authentically myself”

Answer: How you act when nothing can punish you.

That is who you really are.

A few years ago, I realized I wasn’t unhappy anymore.

The main change: living life noting “good days” and “bad days”. 

Then, looking for the things I could control that happened on good days.  

Then, deliberately repeating them.

This lead me here: 
1) I eat the same stuff. This minimized bad food experiences and kept me in shape. Which always made me feel better than not being in shape. 

2) I lift weights with people I like. I noticed I always had good days if I worked out with people I liked.

3) I work on something I could see visible progress on (I write everyday). I noticed when I did that, I felt some larger accomplishment.

3.5) Later I realized if I did that activity with a friend, it made it even more enjoyable. Which is what has given birth to @DrKashey and my daily writing sessions.

4) I unwind with a nice view. I noticed when I had a dedicated place to sit quietly and read or reflect my days went better.

That’s about all I’ve got that actually made me less unhappy. 

Simply paying attention to what happened on good days then trying to recreate it might’ve been one of the most valuable things I’ve done for myself. 

TLDR: I spend as much time as I can doing things I like with people I like and ignore as much of everything else as I can.

If you want to build a valuable business, your objectives should to ladder up to:

1) Get more customers 
2) Make them worth more 
3) Decrease risk

If they don’t, they’re probably not good objectives.

People want to find their passion. 
But you don’t find it, you create it. 
And you create by getting good at something. 
And to get good at stuff, you start by doing something you suck at.
Then, you get good.
Then, you like it.
Then, people ask you how you found your passion.

Answer: By starting when you sucked and not giving up.
It always takes longer and costs more than you think it will.

Then ignore what they say. 
Then tell them what to do. 
And they do it
And it fails. 
Then you blame them for not hitting your goals. 
You should be fired.

You do what must be done. Period.

Most people underestimate the things they have to say no to when building.

Everything you say yes to is saying no to the thing you say you want most.

So you have to say no until it hurts.
Then say no some more.

So you can take one yes all the way.

Occasionally I speak at events…and someone will inevitably say they can’t do something because [insert reason: Kids. Time. Money. Etc.] , then imply that they can’t be successful because of it.

Rather than fight them, I’ve leaned into just saying “you’re right. You’re never gonna win”

Then they get really razzled and start arguing with me about how that’s not true. And once they’ve made a ton of really convincing points, I simply agree with them. 

Then, everyone wins.

Dreams are never too big. 

Only too big for the person hearing them.

My grandfather would say to my father who then said to me: “No matter how rich you get, chicken is still chicken and rice is still rice.”

And it’s true. 

A decade later. I still eat the same ground meat and rice with (a lot) of hot sauce. 

Cheers to the little things.
If at first you fail, use force.

Work doesn’t discriminate on the fuel you use to get it done.

Passion is great.

But anger will do.
Hate only wins when you listen to it.

The first is forgivable, the second isn’t.

Sometimes you just have to shut the fuck up and do shit you don’t wanna do so you can get what you want and ignore everyone who tells you otherwise.

The work week starts and ends when you say it does.

You have four 12-week sprints until the year is over. 

There’s no bigger waste than spend them talking about what you’re *gonna do.*
If you want people to think you’re a lot smarter than you are, come prepared.

Contrary to popular belief:

To get the most people to buy, sell at the time of greatest need, not greatest value.

A thirsty man is more likely to buy water before he drinks it.

How to make friends with people ahead of you:

Give. Never ask.

If you want things to go faster, check in more times.

Nothing says *it’s urgent* like checking back every two hours.…instead of every two weeks.
If you think it’ll be easy, you just don’t know enough about it yet.

How to know someone doesn’t know enough about a new opportunity:

They think it’ll be easy.

When I started going after bigger goals, I found it more useful to write down what I was gonna give up more than what I was gonna do.

And - in general - the bigger the goal, the bigger the sacrifice.

Advice to 20 year olds:

Do shit before teaching how to do shit.
The hard part of the plan isn’t making the plan, it’s sticking with the plan.

And if they make fun of you working your ass off before it pays off - they don’t matter.

You always look crazy until it works.

Writing a book is hard. Writing a great book is harder. Writing one that actually gets read…the hardest. 

I think when I die I’ll be most proud of my books speaks to why I put so much time into them. 

Anyways thank you all for your support. On Jan 1 2024, it cracked 20,000 Amazon reviews with a 4.9 rating. We’ve sold over 850,000 copies now.

It’s wild how much publishing a purple book 2.5 years ago has changed about my life.

Working hard on volume 3 of the $100M book series. You’re gonna love it. It’s the sexiest of the book topics.

The worst thing that can happen is when they would’ve said yes, but you never asked.

Ask.

How to invest your first $10k:

Answer: Don’t.

1) Go thru courses or workshops online.
2) Spend the $ trying to make it work. 
3) Repeat until you make more money than you can invest in skills. 

4) Then take the extra and invest in assets outside yourself.

Til then. Repeat 1-3

It’s easier to switch environments than to change them.

So if you don’t like who you are right now, move.

The only thing worse than making a $1000 offer to a person with a $100 budget is making a $100 offer to someone with a $1000 budget. 

You lose 9x the money by not having something more valuable to sell.

Underrated advice:

If you don’t like who you are - change where you are.
Personal growth is a long process of turning down the volume on what other people think of us and turning up the volume on we think of us.

Easiest way to change what you do is to change where you are.

It’s easier to go somewhere else to be someone else than to try and break the gravity of other people’s ingrained expectations.

How to change your life this year more than any New Year’s goal:

Cut bad friends. Make new ones.

If you change your behavior this year, people will notice.

They’ll try and get you back in line with their mediocre expectations of you. 

Dont let them. 

Deal with their disappointment for a season so you don’t have to deal with your own for a lifetime.

And - get new friends.

Reminder for anyone trying to start or stop habits. 

If you’re stopping something, find a new behavior to replace it with. 

If you’re starting something, pick a current behavior to delete the new one with.

Your time is 100% accounted for. 
You don’t add or subtract - you swap.
Here’s your friendly reminder not to ask for advice this year you’re not gonna follow.

Be someone who says they’re gonna do something then doesn’t do it.

Spend less than you make.

Everything else just builds on it.

I can’t help but think…so you want someone you can replace with a $40,000 a year employee?

Expect more.

Give me praise in public.

New year reminder:

The last chapter of our life story is already written: we die.

Might as well fill the rest with epic stories of daring greatly and do what you’ve always wanted to do until that day comes.

Just do what you said you were gonna do before it became inconvenient.

Giving gifts when you both work together and make the same money is weird.

You’re like “So how much money you wanna spend?”

Not a lot of romanticism. 
Feels like an expense. 

Highlights another exit from normal living that married entrepreneurs have.
Merry Christmas.

Few things I agree with more:

“There is only one good, knowledge, and only one evil, ignorance.” - Socrates.

It’s about getting everything you can out of all you’ve got - not coming up with new and more creative excuses for why you have a disadvantage.

Because underdogs have one advantage no one else has: nothing to lose.

Repeated entrepreneur mistake:

Encountering a new problem and assuming the only solution is to change your entire business as though the new problems in the new business you’ll somehow already know how to solve.

Oftentimes, that means just starting.

How to be unhappy:

No matter how happy you are, think you should be happier.
Free time on your calendar gives you the time to work on the things that matter most rather than what’s most timely.

Many make money selling education because the demand for earning income has never gone away. 

People just realized the suppliers of it (4 year degrees) weren’t providing it. 

So, the demand shifted. 

This money is just a fraction of what these schools monopolized for years.

Then I remember:
“Right. Holidays. Those. Yes. Human things.”

If you don’t track, you don’t care.

The store owner is better off with the money. 

The customer is better off with the product. 

The system nets a positive with the same resources in new hands.

A way to separate signal from noise:

Take people’s observations and toss their explanations. 

The first is fact, the second is storytelling.

It’s normal not to know what you’re doing. 

If you did, it wouldn’t be called growth. 

High-five your fear, uncertainty, & doubt and carry on.

Hot take:

You don’t have to wait until January 1st to better yourself.

The only point of suffering is learning. 

If you learn nothing, it was for nothing.

*Entrepreneur’s Daily Battle Hymn*

I will get there. 

For now, I grind.

It will pay off.

In what I build.

Or who I become. 

I hit my goal.

Or I grow.

Either way.

I win.

And if your stuff is good, they’ll pay to try it again.

First success habit:

Separate failing from being a failure.
The things that trigger you are the things that control you.

Something that took me a few sleepless nights to learn:

If someone starts hating on you out of the blue…

…and you haven’t talked to them or about them since you last spoke. 

It’s a “them” thing not a “you” thing.

Doing the basics with ruthless consistency and precision is what makes you advanced, not complexity.

You don’t get bigger by trying to get bigger. 

You get bigger by getting better.

Growth then happens as a natural consequence of more people wanting your better stuff.
The hard part of friendship isn’t outgrowing them, it’s drawing new boundaries once you do.

“I work all the time, I can’t find time to pursue X”

2000 work hours 
6760 non work hours 

You literally have 3+ hours for every 1 hour of work assuming a 40hr workweek.

Never been a better time to use 78% (!!) of your time to figure out how to enjoy your life.

Your current group isn’t going to let you rise up. 

That’s why it’s called breaking out, breaking free, and breaking through.

You’re not gonna get to the next level staying in the box they like you in.  

Sometimes you gotta hurt feelings and break shit.

Best job to have when going after your dreams:

One where you get 129 days a year off to pursue your dreams with full-time pay. 

Oh yea, that’s every 9-5 job.

No excuses.

You will get there. 

For now, you grind.

It will pay off.

Either in what you build or who you become along the way.

Those who skip to teaching people how to make money before they actually made money.

Time saving hack:

Remove people from your life who are only there for what they can get from you.
As long as you don’t let your first failure become your last failure it wasn’t a failure.

If you’re not sure how to improve your marketing:

1) Say the same thing in half the space. 
2) Only use words 3rd graders know.

When people are in a rush (everyone) simple beats sexy.

How to become confident in any skill:

Do it so many times you get bored of doing it.
You’ll never accomplish everything you want to because it takes less time to see a path than to walk it.
Successful people become successful by learning to fail without becoming failures.

If you don’t know what to get an entrepreneur for the holidays:

Buy their product at full price and leave them a review.

Real friends don’t ask for ‘friend discounts.’

They pay full price and leave a review.

1) Love winning
2) Hate losing
3) Love playing

But only #3 makes it fun the whole time.

Because if the easy thing were the right thing, you would’ve already done it.

False. 

How you treat your mother is how you treat your mother.

Just because people say it doesn’t make it true.

Surprisingly effective:

When arguing it’s easier to get people to disagree with you than agree. 

So disagree with your desired outcome, argue, then let them have it “their way.”

Just because they said no for now doesn’t mean they said no forever. 

And just because they said no to this offer doesn’t mean they’re saying no to every offer. 

Personalize, don’t pressure.

You only get the sales you listen for.

…with that new business idea you start

My favorite response to hate comments:

What if they’re right?

Then go down the rabbit hole.

It permanently transforms hot buttons into obvious observations you agree with.

“Alex wants to make money” - yes, I agree with you.

“Alex isn’t as cool as people think he is.” - yes I agree with you. 

“You’re an idiot.” - yes, I agree with you.

“This guys numbers are fake.” - I don’t agree with you, but they’re honestly more unbelievable to me than they are to you because I live with them. So I get it. 

“He probably rented that private jet.” - you’re right. Chartering is renting. We agree. 

“He’s on steroids.” - yep. I’m on testosterone. And if u take ‘more’ they become steroids.

So you kinda just say “yea - I get it” rather than fighting it. And it uses up a lot less mental energy. 

Because the worst case is they make a point about your flaws. 

And if you were ‘t trying to publicly save face, you’d probably agree. 

‘Yea I am an idiot sometimes. Yea I can be selfish. Yea I could’ve made that better…etc’

This all stemmed from a question about ‘hate’ comments. 

And the honest truth is - I think I come to agree with most of them. 

Which transformed them from hate into ‘observations I agree with’. Which I have no reason to fight.

Ways to not feel stressed when ‘bad’ stuff happens:

1) Decide it isn’t bad. It just is. Remind yourself that you’re the one calling it bad. Most ‘bad’ things in the micro becomes ‘good’ things in the macro. 

2) See if you can remember something of equal importance from 20 years ago. If not, it probably won’t matter in the future. And it won’t matter then, it doesn’t matter now.

3) Imagine this bad thing happened every hour of everyday for the next two years. How would you feel on the 1,000th time of this happening? Probably like it’s just ‘part of life’. If it can feel that way then, it can feel that way now.

4) Remind yourself that if you zoom far enough out in space. Right now. That you can’t even see the earth. Reminds us that big problems are only big when compared to small things. Change what you compare your problems to, and they become small problems (or stop being one all together).

5) Remind yourself that right now. We remember entire civilizations as the ancient “X-ans”. Romans. Sumerians. Babylonians. And we may be the Ancient Americans to a future gen. Barely even remembering names of leaders. If we can’t remember their names, their problems certainly didn’t matter.

6) Jail. Bankruptcy. Ridicule. Whatever “terrible” thing it is. Be grateful that you get to have this unique human experience. Most people may not ever experience it. But you can. Which gives you deeper insight no one can take from you. And that’s something to be grateful for. 

7) Remind yourself that the output of hard circumstances is strong character. After all, hard people don’t come from easy times. So we can’t wish for one without the other. In many cases, we’re getting our wish - to become the best version of ourselves. And this is just the way we become it.

These frames have helped me more than I can say. Hope they helps you.

My dad used to tell me:

“I don’t play a game unless I know I’m going to win”

And some might take that as trying to only go after safe bets. 

But he meant it - and I took it - to mean something entirely different.

What he was articulating - in his way - was the idea of having “unfair” (not unethical) advantages in a game.

It’s a tiny thing, but it’s something I continue to give more and more thought to. 

“How can I rig this game so I can’t lose?”

In one way - it’s about eliminating downside. 

In the other - it’s about maximizing upside. 

And as a mental framework when approaching investments in a business - it’s one I use a lot. 

How can we make it so we can’t lose?

How can we make it is winning is inevitable?

The big variable that confounds results is a four letter word - Time. 

What is winning?
When do we measure it?

And most times - when people talk about winning - they talk about it on different timeliness. And that’s what creates confusion.

The nice thing is though - if you want a win tomorrow - it’s gonna be hard to engineer and there’s a lot of competition. See: Day-trading and Jim Simmons. 

But if you’re willing to expand the time horizon you can engineer most games to be un-loseable. 

It’s because there’s little competition when you compete on a 20 year time horizon. So there’s plenty of room for big obvious moves.

Then, you just gotta give time, time.

Then make it real.

I’ve said that you should offer to work for free for someone to learn from them. Two caveats:

1) Go for someone 1-2 steps ahead of you, not 20. Elon musk doesn’t need someone getting his coffee.

2) Don’t offer to do stuff for free. DO IT. Don’t ask “how can I provide value?”

^It’s now costing me time to try and figure out a way for you to provide value to me.

Be an adult. Do your homework. Figure out what you can do. Then DO IT. And expect that the person won’t care. 

Then keep doing it. And if it’s good, they’ll give you a shot. 

You gotta remember - you’re the one with everything to gain here. 

Low skilled labor is not in short supply. And training people is expensive.

So - if you want someone further ahead to give you a hand, give them something they’d wanna stick out their hand for. 

And if no one is taking you up on your offer, you’ve gotta make it better. Simple as that. 

And real talk - sometimes timing isn’t right. I had someone ask to translate one of my books for me. I was distracted. And I said I don’t have time for this now. Guy took it personally. 6 months later I hired a book manager and we’re translating in a lot of languages now. If he reached out now - it would probably work out. No different effort. Just timing FOR ME. 

An offer I would take is something that helps me NOW. Make my life easier and faster INCLUDING the interaction w the person (hard hurdle). 

Real real - if you wanna do something for me you’re probably gonna have to do work for a leader in my company. Then they’ll offer you a job and I won’t be involved. 

Anyways - the work for free cheat sheet:
1) Target people a couple steps ahead not eons ahead. 
2) Provide the value first. Don’t ask what you can do.
3) Make then an offer so good theyd feel stupid saying no: what they want, easier, faster, risk free. 

—>and realize that the timing may not be right - and be willing to ask more than one person or ask again in the future without getting butthurt.

To Ivante - the young man who stopped me at the grocery store working 2 jobs with a 1 year old who asked for advice on how to get ahead - I gave you a short answer because I was in a rush and it ate at me. So if you follow me here, maybe you’ll read this.

What you’re going through is tough. 
Being so young and already having to support a child is not easy.
But you’ll have the opportunity to become an amazing inspiration in a way I never could. Your success story will become your sermon.

That being said - onto the advice:

You’re gonna need to assume luck isn’t real. Or that it applies to everyone else but you.
Because the only way you’re gonna get out of your surroundings is by having something of value other people want.

And right now, the only thing you have is your time - with low skills - to trade.

Which is a hard game to play.

You’ll have to trade a lot only to get a little.

So - you’re main objective is to have the time to learn a skill while providing for your family.

That means, in the short term, your family may have to suffer. Scratch that. Your family will suffer. But better now when they’re too young to remember than when they’re too old to forget.

Again, not forever. But for now. 

So these are the things you’re gonna have to do. And this isn’t ‘dabble’ stuff. 

This is - wake the f*ck up because if you don’t - you’re gonna blink and be 30 in the same spot, but worse. 

1) Cut all costs. And I mean ALL costs. You don’t eat out anymore. For anything. And if you’re hungry, you deal with it. If it’s not from a discount grocery store, you don’t buy it. Clothing - ha! What you’ve got is everything you need for the next two years. Period. No exceptions. Reuse. Trade or go to goodwill. You go to work. You go home. And home - is ideally with your family, or worst case, with another family also trying to make it and save. And it’s gotta be as cheap as you possible.

2) Increase your income. You’re working two jobs. Your free time, spend applying to other jobs closer to what you want to do. Any at home phone sales job has starter roles that require zero experience that pay $40k/yr or more. Do that, and work your other job in between. If you can’t, drive Uber. If you don’t have a car, save up until you do.

3) The easiest thing to sell is someone else’s stuff. So start there. Then, learn how to buy stuff for cheap and flip it. The bigger the thing, the more you make. You go from flipping cards to furniture to homes. And the limit never really stops there.  

Final note: I could hear the stress in your voice when you were talking to me about your situation. It sounded like you didn’t know what to do. Sadness comes from a lack of options. It’s a feeling of hopelessness. But whenever you feel that, I want you to think ‘this is ignorance not sadness—it means I don’t know enough, and that, I can control.’

You asked to come work for free for me. 

But I have no need for low skilled labor. 

But I do have need for high skilled beasts. 

It’s why I make the books and the courses and the content, everywhere, for free.

So use those. Then get yourself a higher paying job. And everyday apply for higher paying ones (I recommend sales to start). 

Then once you get in there - for the love of god work until your fingers bleed because you have no other option. 

You have no luck. Nothing is gonna work out in your favor. You’re not gonna catch a break. 

You’re gonna have to make it happen. You’re gonna have to force it.

You’ve gotta become undeniable. 

And the best news is - you can do that in less than a year. 

So that’s my advice: 

1) cut all your costs. Everything.
2) work more to make more. And apply to better jobs. Learn to sell. 
3) Start selling more expensive stuff then eventually stuff you own. 

The game is just trading up. Over and over and over again. You’re just a few trades away from a very different financial situation.
You are not free until you are willing to be hated for the thing you love.

Two men set out to build a building.

One lays the foundation for a 10-story building and finishes the entire building in nine months. 

The other lays the foundation for a 100-story building and it takes him the entire nine months just to build the first few floors. 

The first “being ahead” mocks the second for taking so long. He decides he wants to build his building into a 100-story building to prove how good of a builder he is. 

So he tries to add stories on top. He gets to 15-16 stories and then the foundation begins to crack. He starts reinforcing things. But no matter what, he feels he can’t put anymore on top. 

Over time, the second guy keeps building and passes the first man.

Two years later the second man completes his 100-story building despite barely having his foundation finished by the time the first man finishes his entire building.

The first man, goes to a mentor to ask his advice on growing his building taller.

The mentor tells him “you need to tear down this building or start another one new”

He says “and waste all the time I spent building this one? Can’t I just add it on top if I just knew how?”

The mentor replies “there’s a lesson here: The fastest way to build a 10-story building isn’t the fastest way to a 100-story building. Your desire to grow fast ruined your ability to grow big.”

**

A lot of entrepreneurs build businesses as though it’s a race. 

And sometimes they reach their goals. 

Then they see someone with bigger goals and a bigger business. 

They then try to build their business into that business. 

But they can’t. 

Because the fastest route to a $10M business is often not the fastest route to a $100M business. 

Sometimes big things take time. And often that’s what makes them worth pursuing.

Don’t compare a sky scraper to a townhouse six months into building.

People with a lot of self discipline don’t actually have more willpower. 

They figure out how to alter their environment ahead of time to make it easy for them later. 

So it’s not about “resisting” the cookies right now. 

It’s about removing them from sight two days ago.
